ledge, I gave the prisoner a pen and ink to write the receipt—I believe I saw him write it—I took it up directly after—I am sure this is the same paper.

Prisoner's Defence. I have no doubt this case would not have been urged against me, but for my being as evidence against other parties—he has sworn he was not aware that the ale was in old bottles, and he knows that old bottles were used; and in consequence of that, I have no doubt, this indictment is laid against me, which I was not aware of till last night—the whole sum of money was spent in a supper; as he had promised to give a leg of mutton supper, and to stand a few bottles of wine, provided the job was hushed up—he came home that night in a great passion, and accused Clancey of laying an indictment; and I took the officer to the ticket-porters' public-house to have a glass of brandy-and-water; Clancey and Thomas came to us, and we had ale and porter, and three glasses of brandy-and-water, to prevent any thing going forward against him—the officers then wanted supper, and we went to Shoreditch, and bought 8lbs. of tripe at Mr. Bennett's, and some onions; and we went to a house to have them—I was in liquor, and west to bed; and they had the tripe and the onions cooked—I had the whole money taken from me; sad since then, Clancey has said he would pay the money by instalments, rather than I should be indicted—Mr. Bowring has more than once pressed me to join him in partnership, knowing that my friends were respectable and would support him—I can produce an sight-years' charac
ter, and never was in any difficulty before; and it is, no doubt, to prevent my appearing against him that he has instituted this.

JOHN JAMES BOWRING
re-examined. Q. Did you authorize him to have any leg of mutton supper, and to hush up matters with the officers? A. No, not in any way; the supper was—the same evening that he came home; but when he came in in the afternoon, I asked him for the money, before the supper; and, about six days afterwards, I was saying I thought it was a very extraordinary thing that Mrs. Brent did not send the money, as she was a lady who never required to be asked a second time—I then went out, and when I returned, the prisoner said there had been a messenger from Mrs. Brent, and she would send the next day—in a day or two afterwards I said I would go there myself—the prisoner then left, and I saw him no more.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure that you asked him for the money the same day as he received it? A. Yes; it was not the next day that I spoke to him about it—I will swear I did not give him authority in any way to do the best he could to prevent ray getting into any dilemma re
specting these bottles—they could not get me into any scrape—they might Mr. Basan, I was not in the slightest degree amenable to the Excise.
(Witness for the Defence.)

ROBERT CLANCEY . I remember the dispute with the officer—I do not know when it was, but we had the tripe supper the same night—I did not have any brandy-and-water—the prisoner was the worse for drink—the of
ficer said, it must be the prisoner or I who had laid the information—he and the prisoner went away together—the prisoner tried to pacify the offi
cer—I had some supper with them—it was tripe—I believe the officer paid for it—the prisoner was there—I cannot tell where it was, but it was Hox-ton way—I cannot tell at what time the prisoner went to bed.
Prisoner. You are aware that Mr. Bowring told us to settle it as well as we could. Witness. No, I cannot say any thing about that—I am only a common working man.
(Joshua Holtham, a trunk-maker; Charles Thomas; and Edward Hollo-way, basket-maker, at Hammersmith, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(See page 654.)

div0.p: George Wilson and James Parker were capitally convicted. See page 515.

div1.p:
644.
JEREMIAH GROGAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of December, 1 pair of boots, value 5s., the goods of
John Franklin; and that he had before been convicted of felony.

JAMES FRANKLIN . I live in the Walworth-road, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington, in Surrey. About five or ten minutes before eight o'clock, on the morning of the 20th of December, the prisoner came and asked if we had any worsted shoe-laces—my father is a shoe
maker, and his Christian name is John—I told him we had no worsted ones, we had silk and leather—he asked to see a pair of silk—I went to the top of the shop to get them, and as I returned, I saw him putting his hat on—he asked me what the laces came to—I said 2d.—he said a half-penny was enough for them—I said I could not take it—he went out of the shop—I went out and watched him—I saw him join another person, about five doors from the shop—I followed, and when he got to the turn
ing, he left the other, took his hat off, and ran with his hat in front of him—I followed, calling "Stop thief!"—he ran down a court, and came up with his hat on, and threatened to knock me down if I ran after him, but I followed him into the Kennington-road, met a policeman, and gave him in charge—I returned to the shop, and missed a pair of boots off a nail—he had run down Prospect-place—a man named Clark lives there—after being at the shop, we returned to the court, and met Clark's boy, who asked if we had lost any thing, and his father showed us the boots—there is a school-room in Williams'-court, which joins the houses in Prospect-place—I find my father's mark on the boots—they had been brought into the shop the night before.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Are you quite certain the pri
soner is the young man who came into the shop? A. Yes; he first went down Prospect-place, and then down Williams'-court—I was the only person in the shop—there were persons in the street when I went out—my father was not up—just as I went to pursue him, the shopwoman came

into the shop—I kept sight of him from the time he left the shop, till he came out of the court—while he ran down the court, I saw him at the end of Prospect-place, and when he turned round Williams'-court, I lost sight of him; and when I got up to Williams'-court, he was coming up, and put his hat on—young Clark did not come out till after he was secured—the other boy left him at the corner of Prospect-place.

JOSEPH CLARK . I live with my father in Prospect-place, Newington. He is a turner—on the morning of the 20th of December, I went into the yard of our house, and found a pair of boots—there is a school-room be
tween our yard and Williams'-court—it is a low building—a person in Williams'-court could throw the boots over the school-room into our yard, easily—I took the boots in to my father—somebody told me they were in the yard, and I found them—my father delivered them to the constable, in my presence—I am quite sure they were the same.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to say they never went out of your sight till you gave them to your father? A. Why, yes, I suppose for about five minutes—the wall of the school is in Williams'-court—there is no outer yard in Williams'-court—our yard is on the other side of the school-room from Williams'-court—they must have been thrown over the school-room—I found them about four feet from the school-room, which is about six feet broad—they were thrown about the middle of our yard—I could throw them over the school-room myself—a boy next door told me of it—he was in his master's garden.

WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable L 4.) On the morning of the 20th of December, I was called to take the prisoner into custody—I met Joseph Clark—I went to his father's, and received a pair of boots from him, in his son's presence.

JAMES FRANKLIN
re-examined. I know these boots to be my father's—they have his mark on them.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the mark? A. "F. 5."—we know the size—my father marks his boots in that way—I know them to be the boots which hung on the nail, by that mark—there were others marked the same, but there was not another pair hanging over the rail, of that size—we had sold no 5's that week, and these had only come in overnight.

PETER MCKEAND (police-constable M 153.) I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—I was present at the Town-hall, Borough, when the prisoner was tried and con
victed—he is the person mentioned in the certificate (read.)
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. I never saw him before he was taken on that charge—I cannot say whether I have seen him since—I know his brother.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

645.
JAMES NICHOLLS was indicted
for an assault, with intent to commit an unnatural crime.
NOT GUILTY .
Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

646.
JOSEPH HEWITT was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Ja
nuary, 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Martin.

WILLIAM POTTER . I am an apprentice to Mr. Thomas Martin, of Tooley-street, Borough, a pawnbroker. On the 19th of January, in the afternoon, I was directed to the end of the shop by somebody, and saw the prisoner drawing his hand from his pocket, as if he had put something into

it, and then he looked at some other goods—I laid hold of him, and he im
mediately produced this handkerchief from his pocket—it had hung at up in the shop—I detained him till the officer came, and then gave him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long was it before the offi
cer came? A. About ten minutes—I held him all the time—he did not tell me the handkerchief was falling, and he caught it to prevent its falling—a person at the door said, "What has he done?" and then he said, "The handkerchief fell down, and I picked it up." I had hold of him at the time the officer came—he did not attempt to escape—there was only one person in the shop, but four or five in the boxes—the person in the shop was a stranger—he could not see what he was doing, without turning round to look at him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I saw some yellow handkerchiefs hanging up, and went in and looked at than—I saw some more hanging near the counter—I went to look at those, and they came down in my hand—I said, "Here is one of your handkerchiefs come down"—he said, "I know all about it, you wanted to steal it"—I said, "I have not stolen it, and am not going to run away"—he said, "I will take good care you shall not," and he gave me in charge.

JURY to WILLIAM POTTER. Q. Was the handkerchief out of sight till it was given to you? A. Yes, his jacket was buttoned—I saw his hand withdrawn from his pocket, it had nothing in it—when I laid bold of him he gave me the handkerchief from his pocket.

JOHN STORY . I am an officer. I found the prisoner in the shop—Pot
ter had the handkerchief in his hand—the prisoner was standing quietly there—he certainly denied it.
(Mary Guest—Thomas Hadlam, leather-dyer, Camberwell; and James Drew, leather-dyer; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.
Second Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

647.
WILLIAM PEACOCK and
THOMAS FAIREY were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of January, 4 1/2 lbs. of pork, value 2s. 6d.; 3 1/2 lbs. of beef, value 1s. 6d.; and 1/2 lb. of suet, value 3d.; the goods of
George Putley, the master of the said
William Peacock.

GEORGE PUTLEY . I live in High-street, Borough. Peacock was in my employ for about three months as foreman—in consequence of information I received I spoke to Hack and Wilkinson, and the prisoners were appre
hended—Peacock was not authorized to sell on a Sunday—I do not open shop at all on a Sunday, at any time—if a regular customer sends, I may accommodate him, but then I expect to be applied to, before I allow him to serve—when I engaged him, he asked too much wages, and I said, "Remember, there is no Sunday work."

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Has not he sometimes sold meat on a Sunday for you? A. Not to my knowledge—I never received money from him on Monday, for meat sold on Sunday, nor of any other serrant—I did not tell him I never sold meat on Sunday except on an emergency—I did not authorize him to sell on a Sunday except to my own regular customers—I swear I did not tell him he might sell to my regular customers on Sunday—I never gave him permission to serve any customers on Sunday—it has happened somtimes that a customer may have sent for

a piece of meat, if they had been going out and altered their mind, rather than disoblige them, I have allowed them to have it—I do not recol
lect that that has happened in his time—I believe persons have come for a mutton chop or a neck of mutton during his time.

Q. Did not you find on your desk 5s., which he stated to you was payment for this meat? A. There was 5s. on the desk on Sun
day morning, and he told me it was payment for the meat which had been taken—he told me this in the shop—he pointed out the money to me—when I came down stairs, after hearing the bell ring, the officer was in the shop—I had two other shopmen—neither of them were there—he told me immediately on being charged with having stolen this—the price of the meat found was about 4s. 3d.—I believe Peacock's aunt has washed for him—there was some dirty linen found in the basket with the meat.

JOHN WILKINSON . I am inspector of the police. In consequence of information, I watched the shop on Sunday, the 25th of January, I was on the opposite side of the street, from between six and seven o'clock till half-past eight o'clock—I saw the prisoner Fairey come opposite Mr. Putley's shop just before it struck eight by the church clock—he stood near the curb, looking towards the door, till half-past eight o'clock—he waited there half an hour—he neither rung nor knocked at the door—I observed Peacock open the door—he popped out, and took a hat-box, which Fairey had in his hand, and a basket—he turned into the shop, and was out again in a moment—he handed the basket to Fairey, who walked as fast as he could down towards London-bridge, till he came to Chapel-court—he turned up Chapel-court, and I apprehended him—I laid hold of the basket, and said, "It is all right"—I said to the constable behind me, "Take this man in charge"—I found a belly of pork very wet, as if it had just come from the pickling-tub, a piece of beef, and a piece of suet—I sent him to the station-house, and went directly to Mr. Putley's house—I rang the bell four times before it was answered, and then Peacock opened the door—I said, "We want you, I must see Mr. Putley directly"—he said he bad sold the meat—I had told him I wanted him for robbing his master—I said, "If you have sold it, what does it weigh?"—he said, "It weighed ten pounds"—that be had sold it at 6d. per lb. and there was the money on the desk—there was half-a-crown, two shillings, and a sixpence on the desk—I looked at the scale, and it was quite dry and clean—the prosecutor came down directly, and I took Peacock into custody—at the watch-house, Fairey said the meat was paid for—I asked him how much—he said, it weighed seven pounds, and he had given half-a-crown for it.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there not a cloth in the basket? A. There was a butcher's woollen apron—he said at Union Hall next day, that he put the meat on the apron to be weighed, that it might not dirty the scale, but he did not say so at the station-house—I had not dirty the scale, of the meat to him, as weighing seven pounds—he said, "The meat"—Putley was in the shop all the time I was questioning Peacock, and must have heard all, I should think.

COURT. Q. How were the articles placed in the basket—was the meat uppermost? A. No—the bundle of linen was on the top of the meat—then there was the pork, with the blue apron wrapped round it, and the beef and suet were under that, at the bottom of the basket—I saw the meat as soon as I laid hold of the basket, and pulled it open—it was a flag basket.
WILLIAM ROSS . I am a policeman. I was with Wilkinson, and took Fairey to the station-house.

WILLIAM NYE . I know Fairey by sight—I had seen him near the pro
secutor's shop several times at the door, the beginning of December last, and gave information to Mr. Putley.

Peacock's Defence. When the prisoner came to me on Sunday morn
ing, I gave him the basket, with my linen in it—he said he wanted some meat—I weighed this meat, and made it ten pounds—I put the apron and cloth into the scale—I gave him the meat—he gave me 2s. 6d.—I said it was not enough—he said, "You owe me 7s. for washing, and whatever there is to pay, you must settle it"—I put the half crown on the desk, with 2s. 6d. more, which the meat came to—I told him to go to the Blue Mead tap, and I would come to him, and pay him what I owed him for my washing.

JOHN WILKINSON
re-examined. The door was opened to me in about two minutes—Fairey had got the door of the Blue Mead tap in his hand, when I took hold of him—when I got into the prosecutor's house, the maid-servant was at the foot of the stain—I found a watch and some money in Peacock's box.

MARY WEBB . I am the servant. I heard the bell ring—the prisoner was in the kitchen when it rang, and went down to answer it, but he did not go till it rang three times—he went down the first time it rang—it rang three times more, and then I went down, as he did not open it.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Fairey was in the habit of coming for the dirty linen? A. The bell never rang in the morning, and I never saw any body come for his dirty linen.

Fairey's Defence. I went to the shop for his linen—sometimes I ring at the bell, and sometimes I do not ring—when he came out, I have said to him, "If you have a bit of meat to suit me, put it in, that will do instead of the washing"—I said that morning, "Seven or eight pounds will do for me this morning"—he put this in—I gave him 2s. 6d.—he said it was not enough—I said, "You pay the difference, and I will settle it when you come to me"—I was going into the public-house door, when the sergeant of the police caught hold of me, and said, "I have been looking for you a good while, I want what you have in that basket"—I said, "What I have is my own, I have paid for it"—he said to the policeman, "You take him, I will go after the other"—at the station-house, he asked how much the meat came to, and I said, I gave half-a-crown for it.

(Moses Woolf, of Rosemary-lane; John Glanville, painter and glazier, Hackney-road; and Ann Noakes, Green Gate-gardens, Hackney-road, deposed to the prisoner Fairey's good character; and Charles Cook, butcher, Red Lion-street, Holborn; and Andrew Curry, boot-maker, Phoenix-street, to that of Peacock.)

PEACOCK.
GUILTY .—Aged 23.

FAIREY.
GUILTY .—Aged 52.

Recommended to mercy on account of their previous good character.—
Con
fined Twelve Months.
Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

648.
JOHN MASON was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of January, 1 £50 Bank-note, the property of
James Wilson, his master.
GEORGE GRAY . I am clerk to James Wilson, a hat-manufacturer, living in Holland-street, Blackfriars-road. The prisoner had been his

errand-boy for two weeks—I received a 50l. Bank-note from Drewett and Co., No. 13,789, dated the 19th of November, 1834—it was Mr. Wilson's money—I gave it to him, and he enclosed it in a letter, and sealed it, but nobody saw him do it—it was on Thursday, the 8th of January—I entered the note in the cash-book—Mr. Wilson, that evening, gave me a sealed letter, which I suppose contained that note—it was directed to Mr. John H. How, to the care of John Wilson and Co., hat-manufacturers, Denton, Lancashire—I directed the prisoner to take care of it, as it was valuable, and contained money, and to be sure and put it into the post-office—on the Saturday, I was at Mrs. Colston's, and she showed me a 50l. note, which I knew to be the note I mentioned—Mr. Wilson is in town, but not in at
tendance—I have not a doubt of the note being the same—the prisoner came back that day, and remained till Saturday, and then left without notice—he was taken at the Northumberland Arms.

MARY COLSTON . I keep the Northumberland Arms, Holland-street, Blackfriars-road. The prisoner came to me on the 8th of January for change for this 50l. note—he said he came from Mr. Wilson's, and said, "Please to give Mr. Gray change for a 50l. note"—I had given him change the Saturday before for the firm, and knowing he lived there, I gave him thirty sovereigns, a 10l. note in two halves, and two 5l. notes—I had changed the same 10l. note for Mr. Gray the Saturday before, and the pri
soner had brought it—I told him to tell Mr. Gray it was the note I had received from him on Saturday—I have the 50l. note now.

GEORGE GRAY
re-examined. This is the same note—he was appre
hended on the 13th of January—we have recovered 4l. 2s. 6d., and an old watch.

JOHN RIGBY . I am a hatter, and work for Mr. Wilson. I saw the pri
soner come into the public-house where I was, and ask for change for a £50 note for Mr. Gray—the landlady went up stairs, brought the change down, gave it him, and told him to tell Gray the £10 note was the one she had received from him on the Saturday before—he said "Very well"—he went out with the money in his hand, and before he went out he said, "If I should run away with this money, what a funk they would be in"—he then walked out.
(Thomas Hacker, hat-dyer, Union-street, Borough; and John Streatham, a hatter, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.
Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

649.
JOHN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of January, 3 planes, value 5s.; and 5 chisels, value 2s.; the goods of
Joseph Dowden; 1 gauge, value 1s.; the goods of
Richard Ledger; and 1 plane, value 1s.; the goods of
Richard Ockerford.

WILLIAM COTTLE . I am a policeman. On the 30th of January, at a quarter before two o'clock in the morning, I was in Lant-street, Borough, and saw the prisoner carrying something—he popped round the corner—I said to him, "What have you here?"—he said, "My tools"—I said, "What are you?"—he said, "Abricklayer"—I said, "A bricklayer does not use car
penter's tools"—he said, "Well, it is all right"—I said, "I do not know that, I shall take you to the station-house"—as I took him there he said, "Well, I have had nothing to do for two or three months—I shall have something to do now"—he was three-quarters of a mile from the building they were taken from.
JOSEPH DOWDEN . I am a carpenter. Some of these tools are mine—I left them in an unfinished house in Tooley-street—I know nothing of the prisoner.
RICHARD LEDGER . I worked at the building—this mortice gauge is mine.
RICHARD OCKERFORD . I lost thete planes from the same building.
Prisoner's Defence. I was hired to carry them by a man in the Borough, who had a large basket full of them—I was to meet him at the Bricklayer's Arms—I did not know where they came from.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Seven Years.
Fourth Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

650.
JOHN JUSTICE and
WILLIAM PALMER were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February, at St. Mary, Newington, 26lbs. weight of soap, value 8s.; and 21lbs., weight of candles; the goods of
Jabez Pike, the master of John Justice; and
WILLIAM MILLER was indicted for
felo
niously receiving 12lbs. weight of soap, value 4s. 6d.; and 21lbs. weight of candles, value 8s., part of the said goods, well knowing them to be stolen, as aforesaid.—2nd COUNT, for receiving of an evil disposed person.

JABEZ PIKE . I am an oil and colourman. Justice was in my employ, as porter—I sent him on errands to deliver goods—Palmer was the servant of a Mr. Holraan, my neighbour—my premises open upon Holman's yard—on the night of the 4th of February, I received information from Holman, and accompanied him to a cart-shed in his yard; and under the cart, in a box, I saw a quantity of soap, which I had every reason to believe was mine, from having a similar description of goods on my premises—Holman went into the loft, and there was a quantity of candles in a canvass bag—I have every reason to believe they were mine, having candles of a similar description on my premises—I got a policeman, and went to Holman's premises again, and in the interval the property had been removed—the candles from the loft, and the soap from the box—I found near the box five bars of soap afterwards in a nose-bag—in consequence of information we went to a shop in Arbour-street, within fifty yards of my premises, and there saw Miller—I told him I had come for the soap and candles which Holman's boy had left a few minutes before—his reply was, "I have no candles"—I said, "It is no use to deny it; we know all about it;" and then he stooped down, opened a drawer, and produced the soap, and after
wards the candles, in a canvass bag—I believe the bag to be the same as I had seen in Holman's loft—I got a policeman, and gave Justice and Pal
mer into custody—I value the candles at 8s., and the soap at 8s. or 9s.—Miller keeps a chandler's shop—Holman is a carter.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you stated to Miller that what you wanted was some soap and candles, which Holman's boy had brought? A. Yes—the prisoners were all before the magistrate—Justice and Palmer were detained—I undertook Miller should come next day, and he was let go on that—he has been a neighbour of mine many years—he came according to promise next day—I offered the magistrate to become bail for him—the magistrate said as the Grand Jury were sitting, it was not worth while—I have supplied Miller with goods, but not for months past.

JAMES BOOTH (policeman N 99.) I was on duty between nine and ten o'clock at night on the 4th of February, in Newington-causeway—Mr. Holman fetched me to his premises—I went with him and the prosecu
tor,

and saw Palmer—Holman said, "Charles, the policeman wants you concerning some soap and candles"—he said, "Master, I do not know any thing about soap and candles"—he said, "You do, for there is soap and candles deposited on my premises unknown to me, and they have no business there"—I took him into custody—Mr. Holman immediately said there was some soap in a box in the cart-shed, and candles in a bag in the loft—Holman went to the loft, and found the candles were removed—I afterwards went with the prosecutor to the cart-shed, and the soap was also removed—Palmer said he did not know any thing about them—the prosecutor stated that he did know, and, if in case they were not there, he knew where they were, from information he received—I went to Pike's house, and took Justice into custody, and went from there to Miller's—Pike said, "Mr. Miller, I have come for the soap and candles which have been brought here"—Mr. Miller said, "What soap and candles?"—he said, "The soap and candles brought by Holman's boy"—he hesitated a moment, then opened a drawer, and brought out four bars of soap, and then the bag of candles, and laid them on the counter—I took possession of them, and took them to the station-house with Palmer and Justice in my custody—I went back to Miller's house, and fetched him to the station-house—I then went and examined Holman's yard, and found five bars of soap under a cart-shed, behind a large piece of board—Palmer had said, in my presence, that there was more soap in a nose-bag in the cart-shed—I found that—he said he had taken the candles and soap to Miller's shop, and stated to Miller that he should call for them that evening.

CHARLES FEARON . I am a carpenter, and live in George-street. I was at the prosecutor's house—in consequence of what he said to me, I remained in the parlour with Justice—I said what a shocking thing it was for a young lad like him, and what a shocking thing it would be for his father and mother, and if he was a lad of mine, it would almost break my heart—he burst into tears, and said, "What will my father and mother say?"—he stated to me that he had taken about thirty-four or thirty-five cakes of soap, and about two dozen candles, from his master.

JABEZ PIKE
re-examined. I have every reason to believe this is my soap—I have a great deal of it at home—I am more positive of the candles—there are certain candles there which I know—one of them is a candle eight to the pound, a long description of candle, which I know well to be mine—I did not miss any, our stock is too large.
Palmer's Defence. Justice called me out in the morning, and said he had some soap, if I was of a mind to take it—I went up the yard, just opened the gate, and he gave it into my hand.
Miller's Defence. Palmer brought the goods to my house, and asked me to let him leave them till he called for them.
(Several respectable witnesses gave Miller a good character.)

JUSTICE—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

PALMER—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

MILLER-
NOT GUILTY .
Confined Six Months.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

652.
FREDERICK KNOWLDEN was indicted
for embezzlement.

MILES POWELL . I keep a retail beer-shop in Minerva-terrace, North-Brixton. The prisoner was my pot-boy, and it was his duty to receive money, and to account to me for it—we took the score of him twice every day—he never paid me 1s. 4d. received of Mrs. Smith on the 27th of December.

Prisoner. There was 3s. due to me. Witness. I was to give him 3s. a week—he had been two or three weeks with me, and I had paid him, but this time he left me on the Saturday, and his week was not due till the Monday—he received more than 3s. of the customers that day, and he absconded.
MARY ANN SMITH . I have beer from the prosecutor—I paid the prisoner 1s. 4d., on the 27th of December, for his master.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and the

Prosecutor.—
Confined Seven Days.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

635.
NICHOLAS HAMILTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of January, 2 fowls, value 4s., the goods of
George Winter.

GEORGE WINTER . I live at No. 5, Minerva-terrace, New-cross. I had some fowls—I saw them safe on the 25th of January, about mid-day, and on the 26th my fowl-house was broken open, and I missed two Po
land fowls—these are similar to them.

SAMUEL BARKER (police-constable R 203.) I met the prisoner on the road, between four and five o'clock that day—I saw he was rather bulky, and asked what he had under his jacket—he said, "Nothing but an
other shirt"—I put my hand to his side, and said there was some
thing more than that—he said, "Yes, a fowl—my sister, who lives at Greenwich, gave it me"—I asked where his sister lived—he said he did not know—he then said, "Where the fair is kept, and her name is An
derson"—I said, "Let me look at the fowl"—he did, and then I found the other on him—this was half a mile from the prosecutor's—I took the prisoner to the station-house, and then to the cage—I found the prose
cutor, and I went to the prisoner, after he had been remanded—I asked him how he came to find such a curious place as where the fowls were—he then said that Captain Wilson's son told him where they were, and he wished to be lagged for seven years, for he should be better out of the country than in it.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.
